title: How to Grow Tea

steps.headline: Choose the sinensis variant and avoid assamica.
steps.description: There are 2 subspecies of Camellia sinensis – Camellia sinensis sinensis and Camellia sinensis assamica. Some of the technical jargon can be overwhelming, but just remember this: opt for the sinensis variant and avoid the assamica. The assamica can be temperamental and requires a specific tropical climate. The sinensis variant is much more adaptable and easy to grow in a multitude of climates. The full technical name is Chinese Camellia sinensis sinensis. Get your seeds from a reputable source and confirm the variant with the seller before purchasing.

steps.headline: Soak your seeds in water for 24 to 48 hours.
steps.description: Place your seeds in a bowl or bucket. Add enough water to cover them completely. Put them somewhere safe and leave them for 24 to 48 hours. During this time, the seeds will become saturated with the water. This helps kick start the germination process.

steps.headline: Spread the seeds out on a shallow tray.
steps.description: Strain the seeds from the water, then scatter them on a tray in a single layer. Place the tray in a sunny area. Cover them with about an inch (2.5 cm) of coarse vermiculite. Mist them frequently with water to keep them damp.

steps.headline: Wait 6 to 8 weeks for them to germinate.
steps.description: Within that time frame, the seeds will start to sprout. Keep the vermiculite damp and let them grow a few inches or centimeters tall. Once the seedlings have grown 3 or 4 leaves, they are ready to be transplanted. You can transplant them outdoors if your climate is relatively warm. Zones 7 through 9 are ideal, but these hardy plants can adapt as long as the winters aren't harsh. For colder climates, transplant them into bigger pots for greenhouse or indoor gardening.

steps.headline: Transplant the seedlings in spring.
steps.description: The ideal time to transplant your seedlings is in the springtime, after all threat of frost has passed. You can wait until early summer, as long as you keep the seedlings misted and moist. If you’re growing your plants indoors or in a greenhouse, you have a little more freedom. The plants are hardy, so as long there’s no frost and they’re getting plenty of sunlight, they’ll continue to grow.

steps.headline: Plant the seedlings in acidic soil with a pH of 6-6.5.
steps.description: Tea plants thrive in acidic soil. Test yours with a kit from a nursery before moving the plants into the ground. Adjust as needed so that the soil has a pH of around 6-6.5. If you’re transplanting into pots, pick up a camillia/azalea soil mix from the nursery.

steps.headline: Choose an area with well-drained soil.
steps.description: Tea plants don’t do well in heavy soils with a lot of clay. They like light soil that drains well. You can lighten your soil up a bit by mixing in 3-5 inches (8-13 cm) of compost. Depending on what your soil is like, there are other conditioners you can pick up at the nursery to further lighten the soil, if needed. Root rot can be a problem if the plants don’t get good drainage.

steps.headline: Make sure the plants get full to partial sunlight.
steps.description: Full sun is good for tea plants, but they’ll also tolerate partial sun and shade. They aren’t too particular, as long as they get a few hours of full sun! If you’re transplanting outside, be sure to scout out locations beforehand and monitor the sunlight and drainage before putting your plants in the ground.

steps.headline: Plant them about 3 feet (0.9 m) apart.
steps.description: They like quite a bit of room and their root balls get pretty large. If you’re growing more than 1 plant, space them out. Make sure there are approximately 3 feet (0.91 m) between your plants. If you’re transplanting into pots, give each seedling its own pot with plenty of room to grow.

steps.headline: Keep the soil moist.
steps.description: Tea plants love a lot of water, as long as the soil drains well. Check the soil every few days and water the plants whenever the soil feels dry. If you live in a hot climate, be sure to monitor the soil so they don’t get too dry. However, because of their hardiness, tea plants will usually survive a drought. Regular watering encourages faster growth, but dry conditions probably won’t kill these hardy plants.

steps.headline: Protect them from frost in the winter.
steps.description: Tea plants fall into dormancy in the winter months. If you live in a cold climate and have the option, bring your tea plants inside during the winter. Otherwise, you can cover them whenever a frost is expected to protect their foliage.

steps.headline: Fertilize them lightly in the springtime.
steps.description: They thrive best when given a balanced 10-10-10 fertilizer mix. An organic fertilizer, like vermicompost, is preferable but not necessary. If you’re growing your plants in containers, you may want to fertilize them once in the summer, also. However, avoid over-fertilizing tea plants.

steps.headline: Prune them in the fall, or when they reach 20 inches (50 cm) tall.
steps.description: Pruning encourages growth and promotes the spreading of the lower branches. Strong lower branches help your plants grow into resilient bushes. Your plants will sprout tiny white flowers in the fall, so aim to prune them when those begin to disappear.

steps.headline: Give them about 3 years to reach maturity for harvesting.
steps.description: Tea plants are slow growers. You won’t be harvesting tea in the first couple of years. You may be able to get a tiny harvest in the second year, but it won’t be much. Starting in the third year, you’ll be able to start harvesting. By year 5, you’ll be able to harvest regularly.

steps.headline: Harvest them in the spring after a flush of new growth.
steps.description: Your plants will stop growing in the winter. When spring arrives, you’ll see new shoots appearing on your plants. This time of growth is called a “flush.” When the flush happens, that’s your signal to start your harvest.

steps.headline: Collect the first 2 bright green leaves that appear.
steps.description: To harvest your tea, simply latch onto the first 2 bright green leaves that appear during the flush. Use your thumb and forefinger to pinch the leaves gently, and then pluck them away from the plant. These early leaves are the only ones you want to harvest for tea.

steps.headline: Continue this annual cycle indefinitely.
steps.description: Healthy tea plants can live to be 50 to 100 years old! As long as you maintain them properly, you’ll be able to harvest tea from your plants for years to come. Follow the yearly cycle of care: fertilize and harvest in the spring, prune in the fall, and protect them from frost in the winter.

steps.headline: Gently dry unopened buds to make white tea.
steps.description: White tea is a delicately-flavored tea that is made from the silvery-white unopened buds and immature leaves of the tea plant. Some varieties of white tea are made only from buds, without any leaves. Steam the leaves on the stove top for about 1 minute and then dry them in an oven for about 20 minutes at 250° F (121° C) immediately after harvesting. Brew immediately or store the dried leaves in an airtight container for later use.

steps.headline: Brew freshly dried leaves to make green tea.
steps.description: Green tea is made from leaves that have been minimally processed. After harvesting, allow the leaves to wilt in the shade for a few hours, then steam them on the stovetop for about 1 minute. Dry the leaves in the oven for about 20 minutes at 250° F (121° C), then brew. You can also store the dried leaves in an airtight container and use them later.

steps.headline: Wilt leaves in the sun and dry them in the shade to make oolong.
steps.description: After harvesting the leaves, allow them to sit in the sun for about 1 hour. Bring the wilted leaves inside or place them in a dry, shady spot for 10-24 hours. Gently mix or stir the drying leaves occasionally to aerate and gently bruise them. If you wish, you can either dry the leaves briefly in the oven (20 minutes at 250° F/121° C), or skip oven-drying and roll the leaves into small balls before brewing.

steps.headline: Massage and air-dry leaves to make black tea.
steps.description: After harvesting the leaves, “massage” them by rolling them between your fingers and hands. Do this until the leaves become darker in color. Spread out the bruised leaves on a flat surface and put them in a cool, dry place. Allow them to air-dry for 2-3 days. Complete the drying process by putting the leaves in the oven for 20 minutes at 250° F (121° C). Store the dried leaves in an airtight container.
